Effects of Switchable DOF for Mid-Air Manipulation in Immersive Virtual Environments

MyoungGon Kim Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Korea University, Seoul, Korea
View further author information
 & JungHyun Han Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Korea University, Seoul, KoreaCorrespondencejhan@korea.ac.kr

              ABSTRACT
              ?Mathematical formulae have been encoded as MathML and are displayed in this HTML version using MathJax in order to improve their display. Uncheck the box to turn MathJax off. This feature requires Javascript. Click on a formula to zoom.

              ABSTRACT

              In the context of mid-air manipulation, this paper presents the effects of allowing the user to dynamically switch between 1DOF, 2DOF, and 3DOF operations. Such “manipulation with switchable DOF” has been widely used in commercial graphics packages and is increasingly being adopted for virtual reality editing, where the 3D scene is constructed through mid-air interaction in immersive virtual environments. However, its effectiveness and advantages/disadvantages have not been investigated. This paper compares “manipulation with switchable DOF” with “manipulations with DOF separation,” which allows only 1DOF operations, and “manipulation without DOF separation,” which provides 3DOF operations. Using translation, rotation, and scaling, three methods were evaluated in terms of completion time and precision. The experiment results showed that “manipulation with switchable DOF” outperformed “manipulation with DOF separation” in terms of completion time whereas three methods were comparable in terms of precision. “Manipulation with switchable DOF” was further analyzed, and the results showed that the more 3DOF operations led to the shorter completion time and the more 1DOF operations led to the higher precision.

              1. Introduction

              Mid-air manipulation provides a natural way of handling 3D objects. Recently, it has attracted attention in immersive virtual environments (IVEs) because the cost barrier of realizing the mid-air manipulation has been dramatically reduced due to the prosperity of high-quality head-mounted displays (HMDs) and motion trackers such as Kinect and Leap Motion.

              The popular methods for mid-air interaction include “manipulations with DOF (degrees of freedom) separation” and “manipulation without DOF separation.” The former allows only 1DOF operations such as translating an object along a principal axis of the coordinate system. In contrast, the latter provides multi-DOF operations, where the DOF is at least three in general. For example, it is allowed to translate an object directly to an arbitrary position of the 3D space. Many studies have been made to compare the two manipulation methods.

              There exists another manipulation method, which allows the user to dynamically switch between 1DOF, 2DOF, and 3DOF operations. We call it “manipulation with switchable DOF.” It has been widely used in commercial graphics packages and is increasingly being adopted for editing virtual environments, where the 3D scene is constructed through mid-air interaction in IVEs. However, its effectiveness and advantages/disadvantages have rarely been investigated.

              This paper compares “manipulation with switchable DOF” with two methods, “manipulations with DOF separation” and “manipulation without DOF separation.” Using translation, rotation, and scaling, the methods are evaluated in terms of completion time and precision. In addition, this paper analyzes how the distribution of selected DOF affects the performance in “manipulation with switchable DOF.”

              2. Related work

              In order to determine the position or orientation of a 3D object with standard 2D input devices, various interaction methods have been proposed (Chen, Mountford, & Sellen, 1988;Conner et al., 1992;Houde, 1992). These methods have been adapted to physical gesture metaphors, which allow a user to manipulate 3D objects with multitouch-screen input (Au, O. K. C., Tai, C. L., & Fu, H., 2012;Cohé, Dècle, & Hachet, 2011;Wu, Chellali, Otmane, & Moreau, 2015). De Araújo, Casiez, Jorge, and Hachet (2013) developed a multitouch table with stereoscopic projector, where finger trackers were used for both 3D modeling and manipulation tasks and active shutter glasses were used to display floating virtual objects.

              Mid-air manipulation allows the users to directly interact with virtual objects in 3D space. Numerous methods for mid-air interaction have been proposed. Frees and Kessler (2005) presented PRISM (Precise and Rapid Interaction through Scaled Manipulation), which dynamically determined the relationship between physical hand movement and the virtual object motion. They evaluated PRISM with docking tasks. Wang, Paris, and Popović (2011) developed a markerless hand tracker to provide precise, easy, and comfortable manipulation of 3D objects. It was named 6D Hands in that both translation and rotation were supported. Song, Goh, Hutama, Fu, and Liu (2012) proposed a handle bar metaphor which supported 7DOF manipulation without separating translation, rotation, and scaling. Mendes, Relvas, Ferreira, and Jorge (2016) compared five existing methods for 3D object manipulation such as the handle bar metaphor (Song et al., 2012) and 6D Hands (Wang et al., 2011). They found that 6D Hands approach was the most natural. Similarly, Rodrigues, Mendes, Ferreira, and Jorge (2015) compared the handle bar metaphor and 6D Hands method in IVEs. They observed that direct manipulation of 6DOF which mimicked the real-world one was more efficient. Feng, Cho, and Wartell (2015) used isotonic input devices composed of two 6DOF tracked buttonballs to compare three mid-air interaction methods which support 7DOF manipulation. Alkemade, Verbeek, and Lukosch (2017) investigated whether a hand gesture based interface can decrease task load of 3D object manipulations. Shen, Ong, and Nee (2011) suggested a system that allows the users to interact with computer-generated virtual objects using their hands directly.

              The effects of DOF separation for manipulating 3D object have been widely studied. Martinet, Casiez, and Grisoni (2010) investigated the effects of DOF separation in 3D manipulation with multitouch display. Hachet, Bossavit, Cohé, and De La Rivière (2011) proposed a direct multitouch interaction system for 9DOF manipulation. A pilot study showed that the proposed system provided a good user experience. Mendes et al. (2016) proposed a DOF separation method based on widgets. Then, the benefits of DOF separation in IVEs were analyzed by comparing their method with 6D Hands and PRISM.

              Many commercial products such as 3ds Max (http://www.autodesk.com) and ZBrush (http://pixologic.ocm) have been used for creating or editing 3D objects with standard 2D mouse inputs. On the other hand, Unity (http://unity3d.com) and Unreal Engine (http://www.unrealengine.com) provide mid-air manipulation metaphors in IVEs. They include handle bar metaphor (Song et al., 2012), 6D Hands method (Wang et al., 2011), and manipulation with switchable DOF. However, the effects of such DOF switch for mid-air manipulation in IVEs has not been investigated at all.

              3. Mid-Air interaction methods

              In the context of mid-air interaction, our study focuses on manipulation of 3D virtual objects through translation, rotation, and scaling. We will compare three manipulation methods (1) with DOF separation, (2) without DOF separation, and (3) with switchable DOF.

              In “manipulation with DOF separation,” all of translation, rotation, and scaling have 1DOF. For example, translation at a time is made along either x-, y-, or z-axis, but 2DOF translation such as sliding on the xy-plane is not allowed. In “manipulation without DOF separation,” however, an object can be translated to an arbitrary position of 3D space in manipulation. On the other hand, “manipulation with switchable DOF” allows the user to dynamically choose between 1DOF, 2DOF, and 3DOF operations. Note that, in all of three methods, translation, rotation, and scaling are not performed simultaneously.

              Scaling in 3D space is determined by three scaling factors along the x-, y-, and z-axes. If they are identical, the scaling is called uniform. Otherwise, it is a non-uniform scaling. In mid-air interaction, non-uniform scaling is rarely used and research has been conducted mainly on uniform scaling (Feng et al., 2015; Mendes, Fonseca, Araujo, Ferreira, & Jorge, 2014; Song et al., 2012). Our study also considers uniform scaling only, and all scalings in three methods are limited to 1DOF.

              An object is associated with a local coordinate system, which we call object space. The object and object space are stuck together. If we rotate the object space, for example, the object is accordingly rotated. In our study, users manipulate an object using the handles attached to its object space (Conner et al., 1992). Figure 1-(a) shows spherical handles placed at the ends of ±x, ±y, and ±z axes, which are colored in red, green, and blue, respectively.

              Effects of Switchable DOF for Mid-Air Manipulation in Immersive Virtual Environments

              Figure 1. 1DOF translation. (a) Object-space axes and handles. Depending on the relative orientation between the user and object, at least three (left figure) and at most five (right figure) handles are displayed. (b) The x-axis handle is touched and highlighted. (c) The x-axis handle is grabbed and the object is translated along the axis.

              Display full size

              Figure 1. 1DOF translation. (a) Object-space axes and handles. Depending on the relative orientation between the user and object, at least three (left figure) and at most five (right figure) handles are displayed. (b) The x-axis handle is touched and highlighted. (c) The x-axis handle is grabbed and the object is translated along the axis.

              Our experiment was made in a virtual scene created and rendered by Unity game engine. The scene was viewed through an HMD, Oculus Rift Consumer Version 1 (with the resolution of 1080 × 1200 per eye, 110∘ field of view, and 90Hz refresh rate). We also used a motion controller, Oculus Touch, for each hand in order to track the hand and interact with the virtual environment. See Figure 2. To track both HMD and motion controllers, two positional trackers were installed in front of the user.

              Effects of Switchable DOF for Mid-Air Manipulation in Immersive Virtual Environments

              All authors
              MyoungGon Kim & JungHyun Han
              https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2018.1514163
              Published online:
              10 September 2018

              Figure 2. Interaction with virtual objects using HMD (Oculus Rift), motion controllers (Oculus Touch), and position trackers.

              Display full size

              Figure 2. Interaction with virtual objects using HMD (Oculus Rift), motion controllers (Oculus Touch), and position trackers.

              Thanks to the advancement of motion controllers such as Oculus Touch, it becomes possible to visualize the hand shapes for mid-air interaction. Compared with 3D cursors such as rays (Olwal, Benko, & Feiner, 2003) and wands (Suzuki & Kobayashi, 2005), the real hand motions are directly mapped to the virtual hands to enhance the immersion. In our work, the hand tracked using Oculus Touch is detected for collision with a handle. When a handle is collided, it is said to be “touched.” The user may further interact with the touched handle by clicking a trigger of Oculus Touch. In our study, we map such clicking to grabbing, and the handle is said to be “grabbed.” Note that users must first touch a handle in order to grab it. In order to determine if a hand touches a handle, we resort to the collision detection module of Unity. For collision detection, we use bounding spheres of the hand and handles. It is an approximate approach and will be discussed more in Section 3.3.

              3.1 Manipulation with DOF separation

              In this method, 1DOF translation, rotation, and scaling are all made using handles placed at the ends of six axes. If the user’s hand is in the vicinity of an object, its object-space axes and handles are displayed. As the hand gets closer to a handle and collides with it, that is, when the handle is “touched,” it is highlighted. See Figure 1-(b).

              3.1.1. 1DOF Translation

              For 1DOF translation, the user must grab the handle of the principal axis, along which the object is translated. See Figure 1-(c). Observe the differences in skeletal posture between “touching” hand in Figure 1-(b) and “grabbing” hand in Figure 1-(c).

              If the handle for +x is grabbed, for example, the object can be translated not only along +x but also along −x. The hand position is projected onto the ±x axes, and the object is dynamically displaced to the projected position.

              3.1.2. 1DOF rotation

              Unlike translation, for which a single hand is used, rotation and scaling are bimanual operations that require two hands, each touching a different handle. In other words, when two handles are touched, our system interprets the user’s intended operation as rotation or scaling, not translation. Figure 3-(a) shows an example of touching two handles.

              Effects of Switchable DOF for Mid-Air Manipulation in Immersive Virtual Environments

              All authors
              MyoungGon Kim & JungHyun Han
              https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2018.1514163
              Published online:
              10 September 2018

              Figure 3. 1DOF rotation. (a) The x-axis handle is touched by the right hand and the z-axis handle is by the left hand. (b) The z-axis handle is grabbed. (c) The object is rotated by the winding motion of the left hand.

              Display full size

              Figure 3. 1DOF rotation. (a) The x-axis handle is touched by the right hand and the z-axis handle is by the left hand. (b) The z-axis handle is grabbed. (c) The object is rotated by the winding motion of the left hand.

              Between two axes associated with the touched handles, one will work as the rotation axis, and the other will be wound to spin the object. The latter should be “grabbed.” In Figure 3-(b), the x-axis touched by the right hand is the rotation axis whereas the z-axis is grabbed by the left hand and will be wound by it. Figure 3-(c) shows two instances of the object rotated by the left hand’s winding motion.

              3.1.3. 1DOF scaling

              In our study, not only rotation but also scaling is a bimanual operation. In order to distinguish scaling from rotation, we ask the user to grab “two handles,” as shown in Figure 4-(a).

              Effects of Switchable DOF for Mid-Air Manipulation in Immersive Virtual Environments

              All authors
              MyoungGon Kim & JungHyun Han
              https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2018.1514163
              Published online:
              10 September 2018

              Figure 4. 1DOF scaling. (a) Both x- and z-axes are grabbed. (b) Scaled object.

              Display full size

              Figure 4. 1DOF scaling. (a) Both x- and z-axes are grabbed. (b) Scaled object.

              The ratio of the initial distance between two hands (measured at the time of grabbing) to the current distance is taken as the scaling factor. Using it, the object is uniformly scaled. Figure 4-(b) shows a scaled-up object. Obviously, the object can be scaled down.

              In scaling, the user may use the handles of the opposite axes, for example, +x and −x. However, it is not allowed in rotation, that is, two axes must be orthogonal to each other. Otherwise, no rotation is made.

              For scaling, spreading gesture has been widely used (Piumsomboon, Clark, Billinghurst, & Cockburn, 2013;Wobbrock, Morris, & Wilson, 2009). It can be implemented either using two fingers of a single hand or using two hands. In touchscreens, the former is a more popular manipulation metaphor. In IVEs, however, it is preferred to use two hands.

              3.2. Manipulation without DOF separation

              In general, “manipulation without DOF separation” supports 3DOF operations for translation and rotation. They use a white spherical handle placed at the center (origin) of the object space, shown in Figure 5-(a). We call it center-handle. It is larger than the handles associated with the axes of the object space, which will be henceforth called axis-handles.

              Effects of Switchable DOF for Mid-Air Manipulation in Immersive Virtual Environments

              All authors
              MyoungGon Kim & JungHyun Han
              https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2018.1514163
              Published online:
              10 September 2018

              Figure 5. 3DOF translation. (a) The center-handle is touched. (b) The center-handle is grabbed and the object is translated with 3DOF.

              Display full size

              Figure 5. 3DOF translation. (a) The center-handle is touched. (b) The center-handle is grabbed and the object is translated with 3DOF.

              Translation, rotation, and scaling are distinguished using the same metaphor as in manipulation with DOF Separation. If the center-handle is touched “by a single hand,” it is highlighted. After grabbing the touched center-handle, the user translates the object to an arbitrary position in 3D space. See Figure 5-(b).

              For rotation and scaling which are bimanual operations, the user touches the center-handle with two hands. See Figure 6-(a). If the center-handle is then grabbed “by a hand,” rotation is activated. The Oculus utilities for Unity (http://unity3d.com) return the orientation of Oculus Touch of the grabbing hand. When it is rotated, the change from the initial orientation is applied to the object. Figure 6-(b) shows a rotated object.

              Effects of Switchable DOF for Mid-Air Manipulation in Immersive Virtual Environments

              All authors
              MyoungGon Kim & JungHyun Han
              https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2018.1514163
              Published online:
              10 September 2018

              Figure 6. 3DOF rotation. (a) Two hands touch the center-handle. (b) The center-handle is grabbed by the right hand. Then, the object is rotated according to the orientation of the right hand.

              Display full size

              Figure 6. 3DOF rotation. (a) Two hands touch the center-handle. (b) The center-handle is grabbed by the right hand. Then, the object is rotated according to the orientation of the right hand.

              If the center-handle is grabbed “by two hands,” the object is going to be scaled. See Figure 7. The uniform scaling factor is computed in the same way presented in Section 3.1.3, i.e., the distance ratio between two hands is taken as the scaling factor. The only difference is whether the user’s hands grab two axis-handles (manipulation with DOF separation) or the center-handle simultaneously (manipulation without DOF separation).

              Effects of Switchable DOF for Mid-Air Manipulation in Immersive Virtual Environments

              All authors
              MyoungGon Kim & JungHyun Han
              https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2018.1514163
              Published online:
              10 September 2018

              Figure 7. 1DOF scaling for manipulation without DOF separation. (a) Two hands grab the center-handle. (b) Scaled object.

              Display full size

              Figure 7. 1DOF scaling for manipulation without DOF separation. (a) Two hands grab the center-handle. (b) Scaled object.

              3.2. Manipulation with switchable DOF

              This method of manipulation with switchable DOF allows the user to dynamically choose 1DOF, 2DOF, or 3DOF operation. As 1DOF and 3DOF operations were already presented, let us now present 2DOF operations.

              Unlike manipulation with DOF separation, which uses only axis-handles, and manipulation without DOF separation, which uses only center-handle, manipulation with switchable DOF may use both axis-handles and center-handle. In addition, it may also use what we call plane-handles.

              A 2DOF translation is made on either xy-, yz-, or zx-plane, and each plane is associated with its own plane-handle. Figure 8-(a) shows the plane-handle (a small blue square) for the xy-plane, which is orthogonal to the z-axis. It is touched (Figure 8-(b)) and grabbed (Figure 8-(c)) by a hand. The object can then slide on the grabbed xy-plane (Figure 8-(d)).

              Effects of Switchable DOF for Mid-Air Manipulation in Immersive Virtual Environments

              All authors
              MyoungGon Kim & JungHyun Han
              https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2018.1514163
              Published online:
              10 September 2018

              Figure 8. 2DOF translation. (a) The plane-handles appear blue for the xy-plane, red for the yz-plane, and green for the zx-plane. (b) The xy-plane handle is touched. (c) The xy-plane handle is grabbed. (d) The object is translated on the xy-plane.

              Display full size

              Figure 8. 2DOF translation. (a) The plane-handles appear blue for the xy-plane, red for the yz-plane, and green for the zx-plane. (b) The xy-plane handle is touched. (c) The xy-plane handle is grabbed. (d) The object is translated on the xy-plane.

              A 2DOF rotation is implemented using the metaphor of arcball (Shoemake, 1992). While one hand touches the center-handle, the other hand grabs an axis-handle, as shown in Figure 9-(a). Based on the movement of the grabbing hand, the axis-handle floats on the arcball’s surface. Note that the axis-handle’s position floating on the surface has 2DOF.

              Effects of Switchable DOF for Mid-Air Manipulation in Immersive Virtual Environments

              All authors
              MyoungGon Kim & JungHyun Han
              https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2018.1514163
              Published online:
              10 September 2018

              Figure 9. 2DOF rotation. (a) Whereas the z-axis is touched by the left hand, the x-axis is grabbed by the right hand. (b) The grabbed axis-handle floats on the arcball’s surface. (The dotted trajectory of the grabbed axis-handle is drawn by hand for visualization. The arcball is also added just for the sake of presentation. In the experiment, it is not visible to the user.).

              Display full size

              Figure 9. 2DOF rotation. (a) Whereas the z-axis is touched by the left hand, the x-axis is grabbed by the right hand. (b) The grabbed axis-handle floats on the arcball’s surface. (The dotted trajectory of the grabbed axis-handle is drawn by hand for visualization. The arcball is also added just for the sake of presentation. In the experiment, it is not visible to the user.).

              Let {v1, v2,⋯, vn} denote the orientations of the tracked axis-handles. The arcball keeps spinning such that vi is rotated onto vi+1. For this, we need the rotation angle, θ, between vi and vi+1, and the rotation axis that is orthogonal to both vi and vi+1. Using the dot product of vi and vi+1, that is, vi vi+1cosθ, θ is computed. The cross product of vi and vi+1 determines the rotation axis. Figure 9-(b) shows a rotated object.

              Because both axis-handles and center-handle are available in manipulation with switchable DOF, the user may select between them for scaling an object. Table 1 lists eight kinds of operations available in manipulation with switchable DOF. The user can freely switch between them to complete a manipulation task.

              Effects of Switchable DOF for Mid-Air Manipulation in Immersive Virtual Environments

              All authors
              MyoungGon Kim & JungHyun Han
              https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2018.1514163
              Published online:
              10 September 2018

              Table 1. The operations available in manipulation with switchable DOF.

              CSVDisplay Table

              In order to determine if a hand touches a handle, we resort to the collision detection module of Unity. For collision detection, Unity uses bounding volumes of the hand and handles. Then, a hand can be reported to collide with multiple handles even though in reality it collides with one. In order to resolve those problems, the handles are ordered with priorities: center-handle > plane-handle > axis-handle. If a hand collides with both center-handle and plane-handle, for example, only the center-handle is reported to get touched.

              4. Experiments

              In order to evaluate and compare three methods (with DOF separation, without DOF separation, and with switchable DOF), we made four experiments, named E1 (standing for Experiment 1) through E4 (Experiment 4). They are based on docking tasks shown in Figure 10, where the user is asked to make the source object fit to the target object that is immovable in 3D space. The position, orientation, and size of the source are tracked at real time to determine if the task is completed. They are also recorded for further analysis.

              Effects of Switchable DOF for Mid-Air Manipulation in Immersive Virtual Environments

              All authors
              MyoungGon Kim & JungHyun Han
              https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2018.1514163
              Published online:
              10 September 2018

              Figure 10. Docking task. (a) The source is colored in green and the target is in silver. (b) The source is transformed to fit to the target.

              Display full size

              Figure 10. Docking task. (a) The source is colored in green and the target is in silver. (b) The source is transformed to fit to the target.

              In mid-air interaction, rapid and precise manipulation of 3D objects is critical. E1, E2, and E3 are designed with increasing difficulty, and their goal is to compare three methods in terms of completion time (D.Mendes et al., 2014). In contrast, the goal of E4 is to compare three methods in terms of precision.

              4.1. Experiment 1

              The virtual environment is associated with the global coordinate system, which we call world space. For every docking task, the source is placed at the center of the world space. In E1, the docking task can be completed by taking either a translation, a rotation, or a scaling. The position, orientation, or scale of the target is determined as follows:

              From the world space, eight points are sampled, as shown in Figure 11-(a). Their 3D coordinates are ±20,±20,±20. The target will be placed at a sampled point in a translation task. See Figure 11-(b) for an example, where the source is colored in green and the target is in silver.

              Effects of Switchable DOF for Mid-Air Manipulation in Immersive Virtual Environments

              All authors
              MyoungGon Kim & JungHyun Han
              https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2018.1514163
              Published online:
              10 September 2018

              Figure 11. Target positions. (a) Eight points are sampled in 3D space. (b) The target is placed at a sampled point in a task.

              Display full size

              Figure 11. Target positions. (a) Eight points are sampled in 3D space. (b) The target is placed at a sampled point in a task.

              In a rotation task, the target’s orientation will be determined by an Euler transform, which is defined as a combination of rotations about three principal axes of the world space. See Figure 12. Similar to (Frees, Kessler, & Kay, 2007), the rotation angles are set to 45∘. The rotation about an axis can be either clockwise or counter-clockwise, and therefore the number of possible Euler transforms is eight.

              Effects of Switchable DOF for Mid-Air Manipulation in Immersive Virtual Environments

              All authors
              MyoungGon Kim & JungHyun Han
              https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2018.1514163
              Published online:
              10 September 2018

              Figure 12. An Euler transform example. The object is sequentially rotated about the x-, y-, and z-axes, each by 45∘ counter-clockwise.

              Display full size

              Figure 12. An Euler transform example. The object is sequentially rotated about the x-, y-, and z-axes, each by 45∘ counter-clockwise.

              Consider the scaling factors in the range of [0.2,1.8] with steps of 0.2. Discarding 1.0, we have eight scaling factors, with which the target object will be scaled for a scaling task.

              Let T denote the translation that defines the target’s position. Similarly, R denotes the rotation that defines the target’s orientation, and S denotes the scaling that defines the target’s size. T has eight distinct instances, each denoted by Ti. This is also the case for both R and S, and their instances are denoted by Rj and Sk, respectively. In E1, a block is composed of randomly ordered Ti, Rj, and Sk. We can compose a set of eight blocks, where no task appears with redundancy. This set is given to the subject. If a task is completed “within certain tolerances,” the next task is given. If the entire set is completed, another set is given to the subject. The goal of E1 is to complete as many tasks as possible in three minutes.

              4.2. Experiment 2

              In E1, a task is completed by a single transform, that is, either a translation, a rotation, or a scaling. In contrast, a task in E2 requires two transforms to be performed. For example, a source can be made to fit to the target by a rotation followed by a translation, not by a single transform. Specifically, a task is either T+R, R+S, or S+T. In a block, T+R, R+S, and S+T are randomly ordered. We can compose a set of four blocks, where none of Ti, Rj, and Sk appears with redundancy. E2 is conducted in the same manner as E1 (block by block, and set by set) and has the same goal of completing as many tasks as possible in three minutes.

              4.3. Experiment 3

              In E3, every task is a combination of T, R, and S. We can compose a set of eight tasks, where none of Ti, Rj, and Sk appears with redundancy. E3 is conducted in the same manner as E1 and E2 and also has the same goal of completing as many tasks as possible in three minutes.

              4.4. Experiment 4

              In E1, E2, and E3, a task is completed if the source object is made to fit to the target object “within certain tolerances” and therefore it is not appropriate to measure precision in E1, E2, or E3. In contrast, E4 is designed to compare three methods in terms of precision. In E4, we use five virtual objects shown in Figure 13-(a): chair, desk, clock, mug, and teddy bear. In the experiment workspace, both source and target are given for each object, as shown in Figure 13-(b). Table 2 lists the pose/size of the source and target for each object. Each source should be transformed to fit to its target. The subject is asked to complete the task in 10 min. If the subject is confident that all sources are made to precisely fit to their targets, he or she can terminate the experiment earlier.

              Effects of Switchable DOF for Mid-Air Manipulation in Immersive Virtual Environments

              All authors
              MyoungGon Kim & JungHyun Han
              https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2018.1514163
              Published online:
              10 September 2018

              Table 2. Position (x,y,z), Euler angles (θx, θy, θz), and scaling factor S for both source and target.

              Display Table

              Effects of Switchable DOF for Mid-Air Manipulation in Immersive Virtual Environments

              All authors
              MyoungGon Kim & JungHyun Han
              https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2018.1514163
              Published online:
              10 September 2018

              Figure 13. Objects and workspace for E4. (a) Virtual objects. (b) For each object, both source and target (colored in silver) are given.

              Display full size

              Figure 13. Objects and workspace for E4. (a) Virtual objects. (b) For each object, both source and target (colored in silver) are given.

              The result of E4 is analyzed in terms of the translation, rotation, and scaling errors, which are denoted by eT, eR, and eS, respectively: eT =xs− xt2+ ys− yt2+ zs− zt2

              where xs, ys, zs and xt, yt, zt represent the centers of mass of the source and target, respectively, eR =θs,x− θt,x2+ θs,y− θt,y2+ θs,z− θt,z2

              where θs,x, θs,y, θs,z and θt,x, θt,y, θt,z denote the Euler angles of the source and target, respectively, and eS =Ss−St

              where Ss and St represent the scaling factors of the source and target, respectively.

              4.5. Participants and procedure

              Twenty subjects (16 males and 4 females) participated in the experiments. They were undergraduate and graduate students recruited from the computer science department. Their ages ranged from 19 to 30 (M = 22.4 and SD = 2.61). All subjects had normal or corrected-to-normal vision. Only one subject used the left hand as the dominant hand. All subjects had experiences in playing 3D games, 16 had experiences in IVEs, and 10 had experiences in using controllers in IVEs.

              For each of three methods (with DOF separation, without DOF separation, and with switchable DOF), four experiments (E1 through E4) were made. The experiment procedure “for a method” is enumerated in Table 3 with the elapsed time on each step. First of all, the subject watched a tutorial video and did a five-minute practice, where the subject trained himself/herself by manipulating five different objects, shown in Figure 14-(a). Then, the subject started to conduct four experiments (E1 through E4) one by one. For each experiment, the subject received instructions on a billboard, as shown in Figure 14-(b). When four experiments were completed, subjective data were collected by asking the subject to fill a questionnaire. After taking a 10-min break, the procedure presented in Table 3 was resumed with the next method. Three methods were in a counterbalanced order. The entire experiment took about two hours, and a subject was offered 20 USD for participation.

              Effects of Switchable DOF for Mid-Air Manipulation in Immersive Virtual Environments

              All authors
              MyoungGon Kim & JungHyun Han
              https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2018.1514163
              Published online:
              10 September 2018

              Table 3. Experiment procedure per method.

              CSVDisplay Table

              Effects of Switchable DOF for Mid-Air Manipulation in Immersive Virtual Environments

              5. Results and discussion

              5.1. Quantitative analysis of E1, E2, and E3

              Overall, we have seven task categories: (1) three atomic tasks, denoted by T, R, and S, in E1, (2) T+R, R+S, and S+T in E2, and (3) T+R+S in E3. Henceforth, manipulation with DOF separation is abbreviated to separated. Similarly, unseparated means manipulation without DOF separation, and switchable means manipulation with switchable DOF. Table 4 shows how many tasks were completed in three minutes by 20 subjects for each of three methods. It is shown that, for every task category, separated returned the smallest count of the completed tasks and unseparated returned the largest count. In general, the larger the count is, the faster each task is completed. Figure 15 compares the means and standard deviations of the completion times.

              Effects of Switchable DOF for Mid-Air Manipulation in Immersive Virtual Environments

              All authors
              MyoungGon Kim & JungHyun Han
              https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2018.1514163
              Published online:
              10 September 2018

              Table 4. Total counts of the completed tasks.

              Display Table

              Effects of Switchable DOF for Mid-Air Manipulation in Immersive Virtual Environments

              All authors
              MyoungGon Kim & JungHyun Han
              https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2018.1514163
              Published online:
              10 September 2018

              Figure 15. Means and standard deviations of the completion times for the completed tasks reported in Table 4.

              Display full size

              Figure 15. Means and standard deviations of the completion times for the completed tasks reported in Table 4.

              A one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) test revealed significant differences in task completion times among the manipulation methods, as shown in Table 5. For the post-hoc analysis, we conducted multiple t-tests and Table 6 shows the results. It was found that separated was significantly slower but there was no significant difference between unseparated and switchable except for scaling in E1.

              Effects of Switchable DOF for Mid-Air Manipulation in Immersive Virtual Environments

              All authors

              https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2018.1514163
              Published online:
              10 September 2018

              Table 6. Results of the multiple t-tests for completion times.

              Display Table

              In switchable, the user freely chooses between 1DOF, 2DOF, and 3DOF operations. We computed their percentages in each of E1, E2, and E3. Then, we analyzed how the percentages affected the completion times. The result is presented in Table 7. It shows that the task completion time decreased as the percentage of 3DOF operation increased. In contrast, the task completion time increased as the percentage of 1DOF operation increased.

              Effects of Switchable DOF for Mid-Air Manipulation in Immersive Virtual Environments

              All authors
              MyoungGon Kim & JungHyun Han

              Table 7. Correlation coefficients between DOF percentages and completion times in switchable. Moderate values are in bold, and strong values are shaded in gray. (All the others are weak.)

              CSVDisplay Table

              5.2. Quantitative analysis of E4

              The goal of E4 is to compare three methods in terms of precision, and the results of E4 were analyzed with the error metrics defined in Equations (1)–(3). Table 8 shows the results of the ANOVA test. The methods showed significant differences only in translating the chair and rotating the mug.

              Effects of Switchable DOF for Mid-Air Manipulation in Immersive Virtual Environments

              All authors
              MyoungGon Kim & JungHyun Han
              https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2018.1514163
              Published online:
              10 September 2018

              Table 8. ANOVA test results for precisions.

              Display Table

              The differences found in chair and mug might be caused by the initial configuration of the objects. On top of the chair is the teddy bear, and their handles appear overlapped. Consequently, switchable excelled separated and unseparated because switchable took advantage of using more handles. In the case of mug, the orientation of the source can be made fit to that of the target simply by a 90∘ rotation about the z-axis whereas other objects require a series of rotations.

              The multiple t-tests were conducted for further analysis, and Table 9 shows the results. Overall, switchable is comparable to separated and unseparated in terms of precision.

              Effects of Switchable DOF for Mid-Air Manipulation in Immersive Virtual Environments

              All authors
              MyoungGon Kim & JungHyun Han
              https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2018.1514163
              Published online:
              10 September 2018

              Table 9. Results of the multiple t-tests for precisions. In translating the chair, separated had a significantly larger error than switchable. On the other hand, separated outperformed the other methods for rotating the mug.

              Display Table

              It is interesting to observe in Table 8 that the rotation error for the desk is significantly larger than the others. It is because the target desk is much greater than the other objects, as can be found in Figure 13, and consequently the subject had difficulties in rotating the large object, leading to the higher rotation error.

              In switchable, we computed the percentages of 1DOF, 2DOF, and 3DOF operations. Then, we analyzed how the percentages affected the precisions. The result is presented in Table 10. It shows that the translation and rotation errors decreased as the percentages of 1DOF operation increased.

              Effects of Switchable DOF for Mid-Air Manipulation in Immersive Virtual Environments

              All authors
              MyoungGon Kim & JungHyun Han
              https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2018.1514163
              Published online:
              10 September 2018

              Table 10. Correlation coefficients between DOF percentages and fitting errors in switchable. Moderate values are in bold. (All the others are weak.)

              Display Table

              5.3. Qualitative analysis

              After finishing a manipulation method, the subject answered a questionnaire to evaluate the method using six criteria with a 7-point Likert scale (the worst is 1 and the best is 7):

              Q1 for preference of the method with respect to translation

              Q2 for preference of the method with respect to rotation

              Q3 for preference of the method with respect to scaling

              Q4 for efficiency and effectiveness

              Q5 for intuitiveness, which measures if the user can understand the manipulation method without difficulties

              Q6 for sense of agency, which refers to the feeling of being in control of the avatar

              Table 11 shows the means of the scores.

              Effects of Switchable DOF for Mid-Air Manipulation in Immersive Virtual Environments

              All authors
              MyoungGon Kim & JungHyun Han
              https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2018.1514163
              Published online:
              10 September 2018

              Table 11. Means of scores in 7-point Likert scale.

              Display Table

              The ANOVA test revealed significant differences in Q1 (F = 16.2615, p < 0.05), Q2 (F = 8.4546, p < 0.05), and Q4 (F = 11.2946, p < 0.05). For post-hoc analysis, we conducted paired t-test. In Q1, significant differences were found between separated and unseparated (t = 4.9309, p < 0.05) and between separated and switchable (t = 5.1415, p < 0.05); separated had a significantly lower score. In Q2, significant differences were found between unseparated and switchable and between separated and switchable; switchable had a significantly higher score. In Q4, significant differences were found between all pairs of methods; separated had a significantly lower score whereas switchable had a significantly higher score.

              5.4. Discussion

              Our hypothesis was that switchable outperforms the other methods in terms of both completion time and precision. However, the experiment results showed that switchable outperformed separated only in terms of completion time, and all of three methods were comparable in terms of precision. This could be explained by several participants’ verbal feedbacks: “Given only five minutes, we felt some difficulties in practicing the switchable-DOF manipulation method because there were many virtual handles to interact with.”

              According to the qualitative analysis, the participants considered switchable more efficient and effective than the other methods. The additional quantitative analysis of switchable showed that the more 3DOF operations resulted in the shorter completion time and the more 1DOF operations resulted in the higher precision. We envision that, with elaborate designs for effectively switching between 1DOF and 3DOF operations, switchable can be made an attractive method for virtual object manipulation.

              6. Conclusion

              This paper compared three mid-air manipulation methods, which are “with DOF separation,” “without DOF separation,” and “with switchable DOF.” For this, four docking-based experiments were conducted. The goal of the first three experiments was to compare the manipulation methods in terms of completion time whereas that of the last experiment was to compare the methods in terms of precision.

              The experiment results showed that manipulation with switchable DOF outperformed manipulation with DOF separation in terms of completion time whereas all three methods were comparable in terms of precision. The further analysis of Manipulation with switchable DOF showed that the more 3DOF operations resulted in the shorter completion time and the more 1DOF operations resulted in the higher precision.

              Authoring 3D scenes in immersive virtual environments has been a critical issue not only in academic research (De Araújo et al., 2013; and Jackson & Keefe, 2016) but also in commercial development tools for VR such as Unity’s EditorVR (https://blogs.unity3d.com/2016/12/15/editorvr-experimental-build-available-today/) and Unreal engine VR mode (https://docs.unrealengine.com/en-us/Engine/Editor/VR). Such 3D scene authoring capability is often offered in games and apps such as VRChat (https://store.steampowered.com/app/438100/VRChat) and Pavlov VR Shooter (https://store.steampowered.com/app/555160/Pavlov_VR/). In Unity’s EditorVR and Unreal engine VR, the primitive types of manipulation with switchable DOF is supported, but no study has been made on the comparison of the method with manipulations with/without DOF separation. We believe our work reported in this paper can form a basis and give a guideline for advanced studies.

              As discussed in Section 5.4, elaborate designs for effectively switching between 1DOF and 3DOF operations will be needed to make the switchable-DOF manipulations more attractive and popular. A plausible design is to utilize the buttons and triggers of the VR controller such as Oculus Touch. For example, the pinch motion with thumb and index finger and the grabbing motion with five fingers can be implemented by mapping the user’s fingers to the buttons and triggers such that 1DoF manipulation can be activated by using the pinch motion whereas 3DOF manipulation can be activated by using the grabbing motion. This can make DOF Switching easy and convenient. Our future work will be done along this direction.

              Acknowledgements

              This work was supported by the National Research Foundation of Korea (NRF) Grant funded by the Korea government (No. NRF2016-R1A2B3014319 and NRF-2017M3C4A7066316).

              Additional information

              Author information

              MyoungGon Kim

              MyoungGon Kim is an engineer at Research Center of Samsung Electronics Co., Ltd. He got his B.S. and M.S. degrees in Computer Science from Korea University. His research interests lie in user interfaces and interactions in immersive virtual environments.

              JungHyun Han

              JungHyun Han is a professor in Computer Science Department at Korea University. He received a B.S. degree from Seoul National University and a Ph.D. degree from University of Southern California. Prior to joining Korea University, he worked at the US Department of Commerce National Institute of Standards and Technology.
